DOC.HEAD: US May Aid New Leaders in Romania
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration will consider aid to the new government taking shape in Romania once it dismantles the system inherited from ousted President Nicolae Ceaucescu and institutes reforms, officials say. The White House and the State Department hailed the demise of Ceaucescu's hard-line government Friday and expressed hope for a peaceful transition to democracy. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher credited the ``courageous and persistent action by the Romanian people'' who prevailed ``in the face of great odds and despite bloody repression.'' Ceausescu's ouster seemed to foreshadow an improvement in U.S.-Romanian relations, which have been under severe strain, particularly since last weekend when anti-government uprisings began. Ceaucescu's repressive policies contributed to Romania's loss of U.S. trade privileges last year. The administration was about to impose additional sanctions Friday but reversed itself after Ceaucescu was forced out. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said U.S. aid would be considered ``once reforms are made'' by Romania's new authorities. Boucher gave a cautious welcome to the designation of a former diplomat, Corneliu Manescu, to form an interim government. He said Manescu's career has been distinguished and he noted the one-time foreign minister has been a leading advocate of political reform in Romania. Fitzwater said the United States is ready for better relations with the new government if it ``moves along a path of general democratic reform. The United States pledges its strong support and assistance. ``We hope that Romania will soon join the other countries in Central and Eastern Europe which have ushered in a new era of cooperation between East and West,'' the spokesman said. Boucher said the State Department formed a task force Thursday night to monitor events in Romania and ordered the partial evacuation of the U.S. Embassy in Bucharest when the situation appeared to be worsening. With the dramatic turn of events Friday morning, the evacuation order was rescinded but embassy dependents who wished to depart the country were allowed to do so. About 20 chose to leave Friday, Boucher said.
